caption_original:
From Canada’s small towns to its largest urban centres, efficient public transit is vital to communities.

Recognizing that public transit infrastructure systems in communities across Canada are as varied as our landscape, we want to know about public transit from your perspective. 

By taking two minutes to complete any activity below you will be helping us build a better plan for the future! http://www.infraconsults.ca

caption_original:
Throwback Thursday to Calgary’s streetcar network in 1930! 

Public transit has come a long way since the 1930s. Today, Canada has sophisticated transit systems from coast to coast, with infrastructure continuously at work to ensure public transit remains safe and accessible across all municipalities, big and small.

Give us your #ThursdayThoughts on how public transit infrastructure can be improved in your community: www.infraconsults.ca

caption_original:
Introducing Poseidon, the recently named Floating Foundation Installer (FFI) operating on the new Champlain Bridge worksite.

Montreal youth attending the “Futurs Génies” day camp will have a great story to tell about their holidays when they head back to class! After all it’s not every day you get to name and build a replica of a massive construction machine.

And the winning name was Poseidon, which fittingly captures the machine’s impressive strength and important mission – placing large pieces of the new Champlain Bridge weighing up to 1,000 tonnes on the floor of the St. Lawrence.

Campers from the science and engineering camp offered through the École de Technologie supérieure, participated in the competition run by Signature on the Saint Lawrence (SSL), the private partner responsible for the New Champlain Bridge Corridor Project and local MP Mark Miller joined SSL to announce the winners.
caption_cleaned: Introducing Poseidon, the recently named Floating Foundation Installer (FFI) operating on the new Champlain Bridge worksite. Montreal youth attending the “Futurs Génies” day camp will have a great story to tell about their holidays when they head back to class! After all it’s not every day you get to name and build a replica of a massive construction machine. And the winning name was Poseidon, which fittingly captures the machine’s impressive strength and important mission – placing large pieces of the new Champlain Bridge weighing up to ,000 tonnes on the floor of the St. Lawrence. Campers from the science and engineering camp offered through the École de Technologie supérieure, participated in the competition run by Signature on the Saint Lawrence (SSL), the private partner responsible for the New Champlain Bridge Corridor Project and local MP Mark Miller joined SSL to announce the winners.
